M1.name: Crab Nebula
M1.description: M1 (Crab Nebula) is a supernova remnant in the constellation Taurus about 4.9–8.1 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.4, spanning roughly 420″ × 290″. It was discovered by John Bevis in 1731. The Crab Nebula (catalogue designations M1, NGC 1952, Taurus A) is a supernova remnant and pulsar wind nebula in the constellation of Taurus. The common name comes from a drawing that somewhat resembled a crab with arms produced by William Parsons, 3rd Earl of Rosse, in 1842 or 1843 using a 36-inch (91 cm) telescope. The nebula was discovered by English astronomer John Bevis in 1731. It corresponds with a bright supernova observed in 1054 C.E. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Taurus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.4, apparent size 420″ × 290″. Ha and OIII are the go-to filters for filamentary structure. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M2.name: Globular Cluster
M2.description: M2 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Aquarius about 33 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.5, spanning roughly 16′. It was discovered by Jean-Dominique Maraldi in 1746. Messier 2 or M2 (also designated NGC 7089) is a globular cluster in the constellation Aquarius, five degrees north of the star Beta Aquarii. It was discovered by Jean-Dominique Maraldi in 1746, and is one of the largest known globular clusters. == Discovery and visibility == M2 was discovered by the French astronomer Jean-Dominique Maraldi in 1746 while observing a comet with Jacques Cassini. Charles Messier rediscovered it in 1760, but thought that it is a nebula without any stars associated with it. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Aquarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.5, apparent size 16′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M3.name: Globular Cluster
M3.description: M3 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Canes Venatici about 33.9 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.2, spanning roughly 18′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 3 (M3; also NGC 5272) is a globular cluster located 33.9 thousand light years from Earth in the northern constellation of Canes Venatici. It is one of the largest and brightest globular clusters discovered with around 500,000 stars. == Discovery == It was discovered on May 3, 1764, and was the first Messier object to be discovered by Charles Messier himself. Messier originally mistook the object for a nebula without stars. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Canes Venatici. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.2, apparent size 18′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M4.name: Globular Cluster
M4.description: M4 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Scorpius about 7.2 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.6, spanning roughly 26′. It was discovered by Philippe de Chéseaux in 1745. Messier 4 or M4 (also known as NGC 6121 or the Spider Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation of Scorpius. It was discovered by Philippe Loys de Chéseaux in 1745 and catalogued by Charles Messier in 1764. It was the first globular cluster in which individual stars were resolved. == Visibility == M4 is conspicuous in even the smallest of telescopes as a fuzzy ball of light. It appears about the same size as the Moon in the sky. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Scorpius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.6, apparent size 26′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M5.name: Globular Cluster
M5.description: M5 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Serpens about 24.5 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.6, spanning roughly 23′. It was discovered by Gottfried Kirch in 1702. Messier 5 or M5 (also designated NGC 5904) is a globular cluster in the constellation Serpens. It was discovered by Gottfried Kirch in 1702. == Discovery and visibility == M5 is, under extremely good conditions, just visible to the naked eye as a faint "star" 0.37 of a degree (22' (arcmin)) north-west of star 5 Serpentis. Binoculars and/or small telescopes resolve the object as non-stellar; larger telescopes will show some individual stars, some of which are as bright as apparent magnitude 10.6. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Serpens. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.6, apparent size 23′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M6.name: Butterfly Cluster
M6.description: M6 (Butterfly Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Scorpius about 1.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 4.2, spanning roughly 25′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. The Butterfly Cluster (cataloged as Messier 6 or M6, and as NGC 6405) is an open cluster of stars in the southern constellation of Scorpius. Its name derives from the resemblance of its shape to a butterfly. The first astronomer to record the Butterfly Cluster's existence was Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. However, Robert Burnham Jr. has proposed that the 2nd century astronomer Ptolemy may have seen it with the naked eye while observing its neighbor the Ptolemy Cluster (M7). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Scorpius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 4.2, apparent size 25′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M7.name: Ptolemy's Cluster
M7.description: M7 (Ptolemy's Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Scorpius about 0.65–1.31 kly away. It appears around magnitude 3.3, spanning roughly 80′. It was discovered by Claudius Ptolemy in 130. Messier 7 or M7, also designated NGC 6475 and sometimes known as Ptolemy's Cluster, is an open cluster of stars in the constellation of Scorpius. The cluster is easily detectable with the naked eye, close to the "stinger" of Scorpius. With a declination of −34.8°, it is the southernmost Messier object. == Observations == M7 has been known since antiquity; it was first recorded by the 2nd-century Greek-Roman astronomer Ptolemy, who described it as a nebula in 130 AD. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Scorpius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 3.3, apparent size 80′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M8.name: Lagoon Nebula
M8.description: M8 (Lagoon Nebula) is a emission nebula in the constellation Sagittarius about 4.1 kly away. It appears around magnitude 4.6, spanning roughly 90′ × 40′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. The Lagoon Nebula (catalogued as Messier 8 or M8, NGC 6523, Sharpless 25, RCW 146, and Gum 72) is a giant emission nebula with an H II region located in the constellation Sagittarius. Discovered by Giovanni Hodierna in 1654, it is one of only two star-forming nebulae faintly visible to the naked eye from mid-northern latitudes (the other being the Orion Nebula). == Characteristics == Located approximately 4,000–6,000 light-years from Earth, the nebula spans 110 by 50 light-years (appearing as 90' by 40' in Earth's sky). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 4.6, apparent size 90′ × 40′. Ha, OIII, and SII reveal structure and make moonlit sessions viable.

M9.name: Globular Cluster
M9.description: M9 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Ophiuchus about 25.8 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.7, spanning roughly 9.3′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 9 or M9 (also designated NGC 6333) is a globular cluster in the constellation of Ophiuchus. It is positioned in the southern part of the constellation to the southwest of Eta Ophiuchi, and lies atop a dark cloud of dust designated Barnard 64. The cluster was discovered by French astronomer Charles Messier on June 3, 1764, who described it as a "nebula without stars". In 1783, English astronomer William Herschel was able to use his reflector to resolve individual stars within the cluster. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Ophiuchus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.7, apparent size 9.3′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M10.name: Globular Cluster
M10.description: M10 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Ophiuchus about 14.3 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.6, spanning roughly 20′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 10 or M10 (also designated NGC 6254) is a globular cluster of stars in the equatorial constellation of Ophiuchus. The object was discovered by the French astronomer Charles Messier on May 29, 1764, who cataloged it as number 10 in his catalogue and described it as a "nebula without stars". In 1774, German astronomer Johann Elert Bode likewise called it a "nebulous patch without stars; very pale". Using larger instrumentation, German-born astronomer William Herschel was able to resolve the cluster into its individual members. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Ophiuchus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.6, apparent size 20′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution.

M11.name: Wild Duck Cluster
M11.description: M11 (Wild Duck Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Scutum about 6.2 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.8, spanning roughly 22.8′. It was discovered by Gottfried Kirch in 1681. The Wild Duck Cluster (also known as Messier 11, or NGC 6705) is an open cluster of stars in the constellation Scutum (the Shield). It was discovered by Gottfried Kirch in 1681. Charles Messier included it in his catalogue of diffuse objects in 1764. Its popular name derives from the brighter stars forming a triangle which could resemble a flying flock of ducks (or, from other angles, one swimming duck). The cluster is located just to the east of the Scutum Star Cloud midpoint. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Scutum. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.8, apparent size 22.8′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M12.name: Globular Cluster
M12.description: M12 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Ophiuchus about 15.7 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.7, spanning roughly 16′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 12 or M 12 (also designated NGC 6218) is a globular cluster in the constellation of Ophiuchus. It was discovered by the French astronomer Charles Messier on May 30, 1764, who described it as a "nebula without stars". In dark conditions this cluster can be faintly seen with a pair of binoculars. Resolving the stellar components requires a telescope with an aperture of 8 in (20 cm) or greater. In a 10 in (25 cm) scope, the granular core shows a diameter of 3′ (arcminutes) surrounded by a 10′ halo of stars. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Ophiuchus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.7, apparent size 16′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M13.name: Great Hercules Cluster
M13.description: M13 (Great Hercules Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Hercules about 22.2 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.8, spanning roughly 20′. It was discovered by Edmond Halley in 1714. Messier 13, or M13 (also designated NGC 6205 and sometimes called the Great Globular Cluster in Hercules, the Hercules Globular Cluster, or the Great Hercules Cluster), is a globular cluster of several hundred thousand stars in the constellation of Hercules. == Discovery and visibility == Messier 13 was discovered by Edmond Halley in 1714, and cataloged by Charles Messier on June 1, 1764, into his list of objects not to mistake for comets; Messier's list, including Messier 13, eventually became known as the Messier catalog. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Hercules. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.8, apparent size 20′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M14.name: Globular Cluster
M14.description: M14 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Ophiuchus about 30.3 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.6, spanning roughly 11′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 14 (also known as M14 or NGC 6402) is a globular cluster of stars in the constellation Ophiuchus. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. At a distance of about 30,000 light-years, M14 contains several hundred thousand stars. At an apparent magnitude of +7.6 it can be easily observed with binoculars. Medium-sized telescopes will show some hint of the individual stars of which the brightest is of magnitude +14. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Ophiuchus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.6, apparent size 11′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M15.name: Globular Cluster
M15.description: M15 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Pegasus about 33 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.2, spanning roughly 18′. It was discovered by Jean-Dominique Maraldi in 1746. Messier 15 or M15 (also designated NGC 7078 and sometimes known as the Great Pegasus Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered by Jean-Dominique Maraldi in 1746 and included in Charles Messier's catalogue of comet-like objects in 1764. At an estimated 12.5±1.3 billion years old, it is one of the oldest known globular clusters. == Characteristics == M 15 is about 35,700 light-years from Earth, and 175 light-years in diameter. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Pegasus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.2, apparent size 18′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M16.name: Eagle Nebula
M16.description: M16 (Eagle Nebula) is a emission nebula in the constellation Serpens about 7 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.4, spanning roughly 70′ × 50′. It was discovered by Jean-Philippe de Chéseaux in 1745. The Eagle Nebula (catalogued as Messier 16 or M16, and as NGC 6611, and also known as the Star Queen Nebula) is a young open cluster of stars in the constellation Serpens, discovered by Jean-Philippe de Cheseaux in 1745–46. Both the "Eagle" and the "Star Queen" refer to visual impressions of the dark silhouette near the center of the nebula, an area made famous as the "Pillars of Creation" imaged by the Hubble Space Telescope. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Serpens. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.4, apparent size 70′ × 50′. Ha, OIII, and SII reveal structure and make moonlit sessions viable. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M17.name: Omega Nebula
M17.description: M17 (Omega Nebula) is a emission nebula in the constellation Sagittarius about 5–6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.0, spanning roughly 11′. It was discovered by Philippe de Chéseaux in 1745. The Omega Nebula is an H II region in the constellation Sagittarius. It was discovered by Philippe Loys de Chéseaux in 1745. Charles Messier catalogued it in 1764. It is by some of the richest starfields of the Milky Way, figuring in the northern two-thirds of Sagittarius. This feature is also known as the Swan Nebula, Checkmark Nebula, Lobster Nebula, and the Horseshoe Nebula, and catalogued as Messier 17 or M17 or NGC 6618. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.0, apparent size 11′. Ha, OIII, and SII reveal structure and make moonlit sessions viable. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M18.name: Open Cluster
M18.description: M18 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 4.9 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.5, spanning roughly 9.8′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 18 or M18, also designated NGC 6613 and sometimes known as the Black Swan Cluster, is an open cluster of stars in the constellation Sagittarius. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764 and included in his list of comet-like objects. From the perspective of Earth, M18 is situated between the Omega Nebula (M17) and the Small Sagittarius Star Cloud (M24). This is a sparse cluster with a linear diameter of 8.04 pc, a tidal radius of 7.3 pc, and is centrally concentrated with core radius of 0.012 pc. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.5, apparent size 9.8′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M19.name: Globular Cluster
M19.description: M19 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Ophiuchus about 28.7 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.8, spanning roughly 17′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 19 or M19 (also designated NGC 6273) is a globular cluster in the constellation Ophiuchus. It was discovered by Charles Messier on June 5, 1764 and added to his catalogue of comet-like objects that same year. It was resolved into individual stars by William Herschel in 1784. His son, John Herschel, described it as "a superb cluster resolvable into countless stars". The cluster is located 4.5° WSW of Theta Ophiuchi and is just visible as a fuzzy point of light using 50 mm (2.0 in) binoculars. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Ophiuchus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.8, apparent size 17′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M20.name: Trifid Nebula
M20.description: M20 (Trifid Nebula) is a emission/reflection nebula in the constellation Sagittarius about 5.2 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.3, spanning roughly 28′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. The Trifid Nebula (catalogued as Messier 20 or M20 and as NGC 6514) is an H II region in the north-west of Sagittarius in a star-forming region in the Milky Way's Scutum–Centaurus Arm. It was discovered by Charles Messier on June 5, 1764. Its name means 'three-lobe'. The object is an unusual combination of an open cluster of stars, an emission nebula (the relatively dense, reddish-pink portion), a reflection nebula (the mainly NNE blue portion), and a dark nebula (the apparent 'gaps' in the former that cause the trifurcated appearance, also designated Barnard 85). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.3, apparent size 28′. Ha, OIII, and SII reveal structure and make moonlit sessions viable.

M21.name: Open Cluster
M21.description: M21 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 4.25 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.5, spanning roughly 14′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 21 or M21, also designated NGC 6531 or Webb's Cross, is an open cluster of stars located to the north-east of Sagittarius in the night sky, close to the Messier objects M20 to M25 (except M24). It was discovered and catalogued by Charles Messier on June 5, 1764. This cluster is relatively young and tightly packed. A few blue giant stars have been identified in the cluster, but Messier 21 is composed mainly of small dim stars. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.5, apparent size 14′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M22.name: Globular Cluster
M22.description: M22 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 9.6–11.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.1, spanning roughly 32′. It was discovered by Abraham Ihle in 1665. Messier 22 or M22, also known as NGC 6656 or the Great Sagittarius Cluster, is an elliptical globular cluster of stars in the constellation Sagittarius, near the Galactic bulge region. It is one of the brightest globulars visible in the night sky. The brightest stars are 11th magnitude, with hundreds of stars bright enough to resolve with an 8" telescope. It is just south of the sun's position in mid-December, and northeast of Lambda Sagittarii (Kaus Borealis), the northernmost star of the "Teapot" asterism. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.1, apparent size 32′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M23.name: Open Cluster
M23.description: M23 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 2.15 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.5, spanning roughly 35′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. Messier 23, also known as NGC 6494, is an open cluster of stars in the northwest of the southern constellation of Sagittarius. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. It can be found in good conditions with binoculars or a modestly sized telescope. It is in front of "an extensive gas and dust network", which there may be no inter-association. It is within 5° the sun's position (namely in mid-December) so can be occulted by the moon. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.5, apparent size 35′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M24.name: Sagittarius Star Cloud
M24.description: M24 (Sagittarius Star Cloud) is a milky way star cloud in the constellation Sagittarius about ~10 kly away. It appears around magnitude 2.5, spanning roughly 2°x1°. It was discovered by N/A. The Small Sagittarius Star Cloud (also known as Messier 24 and IC 4715) is a star cloud in the constellation of Sagittarius approximately 600 light years wide, which was catalogued by Charles Messier in 1764. It should not be confused with the nearby Large Sagittarius Star Cloud which lies about 10° to the south. Messier described the cloud as "a large nebulosity in which there are many stars of different magnitudes" and gave its dimensions as being some 1.5° across. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 2.5, apparent size 2°x1°. Broadband capture is a safe starting point. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M25.name: Open Cluster
M25.description: M25 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 2.0 kly away. It appears around magnitude 4.6, spanning roughly 36′. It was discovered by Philippe de Chéseaux in 1745. Messier 25, also known as IC 4725, is an open cluster of stars in the southern constellation of Sagittarius. The first recorded observation of this cluster was made by Philippe Loys de Chéseaux in 1745 and it was included in Charles Messier's list of nebulous objects in 1764. The cluster is located near some obscuring features, with a dark lane passing near the center. M25 is at a distance of about 2,000 light-years away from Earth and is 67.6 million years old. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 4.6, apparent size 36′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M26.name: Open Cluster
M26.description: M26 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Scutum about 5.0 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.0, spanning roughly 14′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 26, also known as NGC 6694, is an open cluster of stars in the southern constellation of Scutum. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. This 8th magnitude cluster is a challenge to find in ideal skies with typical binoculars, where it can be, with any modern minimum 3-inch (76 mm) aperture device. It is south-southwest of the open cluster Messier 11 and is 14′ across. About 25 stars are visible in a telescope with a 150–200 mm (6–8 in) aperture. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Scutum. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.0, apparent size 14′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M27.name: Dumbbell Nebula
M27.description: M27 (Dumbbell Nebula) is a planetary nebula in the constellation Vulpecula about 1.148–1.52 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.4, spanning roughly 8.0′ × 5.6′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. The Dumbbell Nebula (also known as the Apple Core Nebula, Messier 27, and NGC 6853) is a planetary nebula (nebulosity surrounding a white dwarf) in the constellation Vulpecula, at a distance of about 1360 light-years. It was the first such nebula to be discovered, by Charles Messier in 1764. At its brightness of visual magnitude 7.5 and diameter of about 8 arcminutes, it is easily visible in binoculars and is a popular observing target in amateur telescopes. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Vulpecula. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.4, apparent size 8.0′ × 5.6′. OIII and Ha help pull out the shell and faint halos. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M28.name: Globular Cluster
M28.description: M28 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 17.9 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.8, spanning roughly 11.2′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 28 or M28, also known as NGC 6626, is a globular cluster of stars in the center-west of Sagittarius. It was discovered by French astronomer Charles Messier in 1764. He briefly described it as a "nebula containing no star... round, seen with difficulty in 31⁄2-foot telescope; Diam 2′." == Location == In the sky it is less than a degree to the northwest of the 3rd magnitude star Kaus Borealis (Lambda Sgr). This cluster is faintly visible as a hazy patch with a pair of binoculars and can be readily found in a small telescope with an 8 cm (3.1 in) aperture, showing as a nebulous feature spanning 11.2 arcminutes. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.8, apparent size 11.2′.

M29.name: Open Cluster
M29.description: M29 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Cygnus about 7.2 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.1, spanning roughly 7′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 29 or M29, also known as NGC 6913 or the Cooling Tower Cluster, is a quite small, bright open cluster of stars just south of the central bright star Gamma Cygni of a northerly zone of the sky, Cygnus. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764, and can be seen from Earth by using binoculars. M29 is well within the several degrees of the arms and bulge of the Milky Way. It is at least many hundreds of light years short of the yardstick distance to the Galactic Center, as is between 4,000 and 7,200 light years away. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Cygnus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.1, apparent size 7′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M30.name: Globular Cluster
M30.description: M30 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Capricornus about 27.8–31 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.2, spanning roughly 12′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 30 (also known as M30, NGC 7099, or the Jellyfish Cluster) is a globular cluster of stars in the southeast of the southern constellation of Capricornus, at about the declination of the Sun when the latter is at December solstice. It was discovered by the French astronomer Charles Messier in 1764, who described it as a circular nebula without a star. In the New General Catalogue, compiled during the 1880s, it was described as a "remarkable globular, bright, large, slightly oval." It can be easily viewed with a pair of 10×50 binoculars, forming a patch of hazy light some 4 arcminutes wide that is slightly elongated along the east–west axis. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Capricornus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.2, apparent size 12′.

M31.name: Andromeda Galaxy
M31.description: M31 (Andromeda Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Andromeda about 2,430–2,650 kly away. It appears around magnitude 3.4, spanning roughly 3.17° × 1°. It was discovered by Al-Sufi in 964. The Andromeda Galaxy is a barred spiral galaxy and is the nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way. It was originally named the Andromeda Nebula and is cataloged as Messier 31, M31, and NGC 224. Andromeda has a D25 isophotal diameter of about 46.56 kiloparsecs (152,000 light-years) and is approximately 765 kpc (2.5 million light-years) from Earth. The galaxy's name stems from the area of Earth's sky in which it appears, the constellation of Andromeda, which itself is named after the princess who was the wife of Perseus in Greek mythology. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Andromeda. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 3.4, apparent size 3.17° × 1°. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M32.name: Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy
M32.description: M32 (Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Andromeda about 2,410–2,570 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.1, spanning roughly 8.7′ × 6.5′. It was discovered by Guillaume Le Gentil in 1749. Messier 32 (also known as M32 and NGC 221) is a dwarf "early-type" galaxy about 2,490,000 light-years (760,000 pc) from the Solar System, appearing in the constellation Andromeda. M32 is a satellite galaxy of the Andromeda Galaxy (M31) and was discovered by Guillaume Le Gentil in 1749. The galaxy is a prototype of the relatively rare compact elliptical (cE) class. Half the stars are concentrated within the inner core, which has an effective radius of 330 light-years (100 pc). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Andromeda. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.1, apparent size 8.7′ × 6.5′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M33.name: Triangulum Galaxy
M33.description: M33 (Triangulum Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Triangulum about 2,380–3,070 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.7, spanning roughly 70.8′ × 41.7′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. The Triangulum Galaxy is a spiral galaxy 2.878 million light-years (ly) from Earth in the constellation Triangulum. It is catalogued as Messier 33 or NGC 598. With the D25 isophotal diameter of 18.74 kiloparsecs (61,100 light-years), the Triangulum Galaxy is the third-largest member of the Local Group of galaxies, behind the Andromeda Galaxy and the Milky Way. The galaxy is the second-smallest spiral galaxy in the Local Group after the Large Magellanic Cloud, which is a Magellanic-type spiral galaxy. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Triangulum. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.7, apparent size 70.8′ × 41.7′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M34.name: Open Cluster
M34.description: M34 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Perseus about 1.5 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.5, spanning roughly 35′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. Messier 34 (also known as M34, NGC 1039, or the Spiral Cluster) is a large and relatively near open cluster in Perseus. It was probably discovered by Giovanni Batista Hodierna before 1654 and included by Charles Messier in his catalog of comet-like objects in 1764. Messier described it as, "A cluster of small stars a little below the parallel of γ (Andromedae). In an ordinary telescope of 3 feet one can distinguish the stars." Based on the distance modulus of 8.38, it is about 470 parsecs (1,500 ly) away. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Perseus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.5, apparent size 35′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M35.name: Open Cluster
M35.description: M35 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Gemini about 2.8 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.3, spanning roughly 28′. It was discovered by Philippe Loys de Chseaux in 1745. Messier 35 or M35, also known as NGC 2168 or the Shoe-Buckle Cluster, is a relatively close open cluster of stars in the west of Gemini, at about the declination of the Sun when the latter is at June solstice. It was discovered by Philippe Loys de Chéseaux around 1745 and independently discovered by John Bevis before 1750. It is scattered over part of the sky almost the size of the full moon and is 2,970 light-years (912 parsecs) away. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Gemini. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.3, apparent size 28′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M36.name: Pinwheel Cluster
M36.description: M36 (Pinwheel Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Auriga about 4.1 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.3, spanning roughly 12′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. Messier 36 or M36, also known as NGC 1960 or the Pinwheel Cluster, is an open cluster of stars in the somewhat northern Auriga constellation. It was discovered by Giovanni Batista Hodierna before 1654, who described it as a nebulous patch. The cluster was independently re-discovered by Guillaume Le Gentil in 1749, then Charles Messier observed it in 1764 and added it to his catalogue. It is about 1,330 pc (4,340 light years) away from Earth. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Auriga. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.3, apparent size 12′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M37.name: Open Cluster
M37.description: M37 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Auriga about 4.511 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.2, spanning roughly 24′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Messier 37 (also known as M37, NGC 2099, or the Salt and Pepper Cluster) is the brightest and richest open cluster in the constellation Auriga. It was discovered by the Italian astronomer Giovanni Battista Hodierna before 1654. M37 was missed by French astronomer Guillaume Le Gentil when he rediscovered M36 and M38 in 1749. French astronomer Charles Messier independently rediscovered M37 in September 1764 but all three of these clusters were recorded by Hodierna. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Auriga. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.2, apparent size 24′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M38.name: Starfish Cluster
M38.description: M38 (Starfish Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Auriga about 4.2 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.4, spanning roughly 21′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. Messier 38 or M38, also known as NGC 1912 or Starfish Cluster, is an open cluster of stars in the constellation of Auriga. It was discovered by Giovanni Batista Hodierna before 1654 and independently found by Guillaume Le Gentil in 1749. The open clusters M36 and M37, also discovered by Hodierna, are often grouped together with M38. Distance is about 1.066 kpc (3,480 ly) away from Earth. The open cluster NGC 1907 lies nearby on the sky, but the two are most likely just experiencing a fly-by, having originated in different parts of the galaxy. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Auriga. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.4, apparent size 21′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight.

M39.name: Open Cluster
M39.description: M39 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Cygnus about 0.8244 kly away. It appears around magnitude 4.6, spanning roughly 29′. It was discovered by Guillaume Le Gentil in 1749. Messier 39 or M39, also known as NGC 7092, is an open cluster of stars in the constellation of Cygnus, sometimes referred to as the Pyramid Cluster. It is positioned two degrees south of the star Pi Cygni and around 9° east-northeast of Deneb. The cluster was discovered by Guillaume Le Gentil in 1749, then Charles Messier added it to his catalogue in 1764. When observed in a small telescope at low power the cluster shows around two dozen members but is best observed with binoculars. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Cygnus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 4.6, apparent size 29′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M40.name: Double Star
M40.description: M40 (Double Star) is a double star in the constellation Ursa Major about 0.51 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.4, spanning roughly 51.7″. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. Winnecke 4 (also known as Messier 40 or WNC 4) is an optical double star consisting of two unrelated stars in a northerly zone of the sky, Ursa Major. The pair were discovered by Charles Messier in 1764 while he was searching for a nebula that had been reported in the area by Johannes Hevelius. Not seeing any nebulae, Messier catalogued this apparent pair instead. The pair were rediscovered by Friedrich August Theodor Winnecke in 1863, and included in the Winnecke Catalogue of Double Stars as number 4. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Ursa Major. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.4, apparent size 51.7″. Broadband capture is a safe starting point. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M41.name: Open Cluster
M41.description: M41 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Canis Major about 2.3 kly away. It appears around magnitude 4.5, spanning roughly 38′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. Messier 41 (also known as M41 or NGC 2287) is an open cluster in the constellation Canis Major. Located approximately four degrees south of Sirius, it forms a roughly equilateral triangle with Sirius and Nu2 Canis Majoris, visible together in binoculars. The cluster spans an area comparable to the size of the full moon and contains about 100 stars, including several red giants and white dwarfs. == Discovery and history == Discovered by Giovanni Batista Hodierna before 1654, M41 may have been observed by Aristotle as early as 325 BC. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Canis Major. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 4.5, apparent size 38′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight.

M42.name: Orion Nebula
M42.description: M42 (Orion Nebula) is a emission nebula in the constellation Orion about 1.324–1.364 kly away. It appears around magnitude 4.0, spanning roughly 65′ × 60′. It was discovered by Nicolas-Claude de Peiresc in 1610. The Orion Nebula (also known as Messier 42, M42, or NGC 1976) is a diffuse nebula in the Milky Way situated south of Orion's Belt in the constellation of Orion, and is known as the middle "star" in the "sword" of Orion. It is one of the brightest nebulae and is visible to the naked eye in the night sky with an apparent magnitude of 4.0. It is 1,344 ± 20 light-years (412.1 ± 6.1 pc) away and is the closest region of massive star formation to Earth. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Orion. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 4.0, apparent size 65′ × 60′. Ha, OIII, and SII reveal structure and make moonlit sessions viable. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M43.name: De MairanÕs Nebula
M43.description: M43 (De MairanÕs Nebula) is a emission nebula in the constellation Orion about 1.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.0, spanning roughly 20′ × 15′. It was discovered by Jean-Jacques d'Ortous de Mairan in 1731. Messier 43 or M43, also known as De Mairan's Nebula and NGC 1982, is a star-forming nebula with a prominent H II region in the equatorial constellation of Orion. It was discovered by the French scientist Jean-Jacques d'Ortous de Mairan some time before 1731, then catalogued by Charles Messier in 1769. It is physically part of the Orion Nebula (Messier 42), separate from that main nebula by a dense lane of dust known as the northeast dark lane. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Orion. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.0, apparent size 20′ × 15′. Ha, OIII, and SII reveal structure and make moonlit sessions viable. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M44.name: Beehive Cluster
M44.description: M44 (Beehive Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Cancer about 0.577 kly away. It appears around magnitude 3.7, spanning roughly 95′. It was discovered by Galileo Galilei in 1609. The Beehive Cluster (also known as Praesepe (Latin for "manger", "cot" or "crib"), M44, NGC 2632, or Cr 189) is an open cluster in the constellation Cancer. One of the nearest open clusters to Earth, it contains a larger population of stars than other nearby bright open clusters holding around 1,000 stars. Under dark skies, the Beehive Cluster looks like a small nebulous object to the naked eye, and has been known since ancient times. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Cancer. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 3.7, apparent size 95′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M45.name: Pleiades
M45.description: M45 (Pleiades) is a open cluster in the constellation Taurus about 0.39–0.46 kly away. It appears around magnitude 1.6, spanning roughly 2°. It was discovered by Galileo Galilei in 1610. The Pleiades ( PLEE-ə-deez, PLAY-, PLY-), also known as Seven Sisters and Messier 45 (M45), is an asterism of an open star cluster containing young B-type stars in the northwest of the constellation Taurus. At a distance of about 444 light-years, it is among the nearest star clusters to Earth and the nearest Messier object to Earth, being the most obvious star cluster to the naked eye in the night sky. It contains the reflection nebulae NGC 1432, an HII region, and NGC 1435, known as the Merope Nebula. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Taurus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 1.6, apparent size 2°. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M46.name: Open Cluster
M46.description: M46 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Puppis about 5.4 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.0, spanning roughly 22.8′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1771. Messier 46 or M46, also known as NGC 2437, is an open cluster of stars in the slightly southern constellation of Puppis. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1771. Dreyer described it as "very bright, very rich, very large." It is about 5,000 light-years away. There are an estimated 500 stars in the cluster with a combined mass of 453 M☉, and it is thought to be a mid-range estimate of 251.2 million years old. The cluster has a very broadest (tidal) radius of 37.8 ± 4.6 ly (11.6 ± 1.4 pc) and core radius of 8.5 ± 1.3 ly (2.6 ± 0.4 pc). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Puppis. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.0, apparent size 22.8′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M47.name: Open Cluster
M47.description: M47 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Puppis about 1.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 4.4, spanning roughly 30′. It was discovered by Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654. Messier 47 (M47 or NGC 2422), also known as NGC 2478 is an open cluster in the mildly southern constellation of Puppis. It was discovered by Giovanni Batista Hodierna before 1654 and in his then keynote work re-discovered by Charles Messier on 1771. It was also independently discovered by Caroline Herschel. There is no cluster in the position indicated by Messier, which he expressed in terms of its right ascension and declination with respect to the star 2 Puppis. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Puppis. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 4.4, apparent size 30′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M48.name: Open Cluster
M48.description: M48 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Hydra about 1.5 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.5, spanning roughly 30′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1771. Messier 48 or M48, also known as NGC 2548, is an open cluster of stars in the equatorial constellation of Hydra. It sits near Hydra's westernmost limit with Monoceros, about 18° 34′ to the east and slightly south of Hydra's brightest star, Alphard. This grouping was discovered by Charles Messier in 1771, but there is no cluster precisely where Messier indicated; he made an error, as he did with M47. The value that he gave for the right ascension matches, however, his declination is off by five degrees. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Hydra. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.5, apparent size 30′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M49.name: Elliptical Galaxy
M49.description: M49 (Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 53,600–58,200 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.4, spanning roughly 10.2′ × 8.3′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1777. Messier 49 (also known as M49 or NGC 4472) is a giant elliptical galaxy about 56 million light-years away in the equatorial constellation of Virgo. This galaxy was discovered by astronomer Charles Messier in 1777. As an elliptical galaxy, Messier 49 has the physical form of a radio galaxy, but it only has the radio emission of a normal galaxy. From the detected radio emission, the core region has roughly 1053 erg (1046 J or 1022 YJ) of synchrotron energy. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.4, apparent size 10.2′ × 8.3′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M50.name: Heart-Shaped Cluster
M50.description: M50 (Heart-Shaped Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Monoceros about 3.2 kly away. It appears around magnitude 5.9, spanning roughly 16′. It was discovered by Giovanni Domenico Cassini in 1711. Messier 50 or M 50, also known as NGC 2323 or the Heart-shaped Cluster, is an open cluster of stars in the constellation Monoceros. It was recorded by G. D. Cassini before 1711 and independently discovered by Charles Messier in 1772 while observing Biela's Comet. It is sometimes described as a 'heart-shaped' figure or a blunt arrowhead. M50 is about 2,900 light-years away from Earth and is near to but narrowly not estimated to be gravitationally tied to the Canis Major (CMa) OB1 association. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Monoceros. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 5.9, apparent size 16′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M51.name: Whirlpool Galaxy
M51.description: M51 (Whirlpool Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Canes Venatici about 19,000–27,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.4, spanning roughly 11.2′ × 6.9′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1773. The Whirlpool Galaxy, also known as Messier 51a (M51a) or NGC 5194, is an interacting grand-design spiral galaxy with a Seyfert 2 active galactic nucleus. It lies in the constellation Canes Venatici, and was the first galaxy to be classified as a spiral galaxy. It is 31 million lightyears (9.5 megaparsecs/Mpc) away and 23.58 kiloparsecs (76,900 ly) in diameter. The galaxy and its companion, NGC 5195, are easily observed by amateur astronomers, and the two galaxies may be seen with binoculars. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Canes Venatici. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.4, apparent size 11.2′ × 6.9′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M52.name: Open Cluster
M52.description: M52 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Cassiopeia about 5.0 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.3, spanning roughly 13′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1774. Messier 52 or M52, also known as NGC 7654 or the Scorpion Cluster, is an open cluster of stars in the highly northern constellation of Cassiopeia. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1774. It can be seen from Earth under a good night sky with binoculars. The brightness of the cluster is influenced by extinction, which is stronger in the southern half. Its metallicity is somewhat below that of the Sun, and is estimated to be [Fe/H] = −0.05 ± 0.01. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Cassiopeia. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.3, apparent size 13′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M53.name: Globular Cluster
M53.description: M53 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Coma Berenices about 58 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.6, spanning roughly 13′. It was discovered by Johann Elert Bode in 1775. Messier 53 (also known as M53 or NGC 5024) is a globular cluster in the Coma Berenices constellation. It was discovered by Johann Elert Bode in 1775. M53 is one of the more outlying globular clusters, being about 60,000 light-years (18.4 kpc) light-years away from the Galactic Center, and almost the same distance (about 58,000 light-years (17.9 kpc)) from the Solar System. The cluster has a core radius (rc) of 2.18 pc, a half-light radius (rh) of 5.84 pc, and a tidal radius (rtr) of 239.9 pc. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Coma Berenices. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.6, apparent size 13′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M54.name: Globular Cluster
M54.description: M54 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 87.4 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.6, spanning roughly 12′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1778. Messier 54 (also known as M54 or NGC 6715) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagittarius. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1778 and then included in his catalog of objects that could be mistaken for comets. It is easily found in the sky, being close to the star ζ Sagittarii. It is, however, not resolvable into individual stars even with larger amateur telescopes. In July 2009, a team of astronomers reported that they had found evidence of an intermediate-mass black hole in the core of M54. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.6, apparent size 12′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M55.name: Globular Cluster
M55.description: M55 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 17.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.3, spanning roughly 19′. It was discovered by Nicolas Louis de Lacaille in 1752. Messier 55 (also known as M55, NGC 6809, or Specter Cluster) is a globular cluster in the south of the constellation Sagittarius. It was discovered by Nicolas Louis de Lacaille in 1752 while observing from what today is South Africa. Starting in 1754, Charles Messier made several attempts to find this object from Paris but its low declination meant from there it rises daily very little above the horizon, hampering observation. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.3, apparent size 19′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M56.name: Globular Cluster
M56.description: M56 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Lyra about 32.9 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.3, spanning roughly 8.8′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1779. Messier 56 (also known as M56 or NGC 6779) is a globular cluster in the constellation Lyra. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1779. It is angularly found about midway between Albireo (Beta (β) Cygni) and Sulafat (Gamma (γ) Lyrae). In a good night sky it is tricky to find with large (50–80 mm) binoculars, appearing as a slightly fuzzy star. The cluster can be resolved using a telescope with an aperture of 8 in (20 cm) or larger. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Lyra. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.3, apparent size 8.8′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M57.name: Ring Nebula
M57.description: M57 (Ring Nebula) is a planetary nebula in the constellation Lyra about 1.6–3.8 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.8, spanning roughly 230″ × 230″. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1779. The Ring Nebula is a planetary nebula in the northern constellation of Lyra,[C] positioned about mid-way between the prominent stars Beta and Gamma Lyrae. It is catalogued as Messier 57, M57 and NGC 6720; Ring Nebula is its proper name. This nebula was discovered Charles Messier in 1779. It has an apparent visual magnitude of 8.8, which is too faint to be visible with the naked eye, but it can be readily observed with a small telescope. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Lyra. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.8, apparent size 230″ × 230″. OIII and Ha help pull out the shell and faint halos. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M58.name: Spiral Galaxy
M58.description: M58 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about ~63,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.7, spanning roughly 5.9′ × 4.7′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1779. Messier 58 (also known as M58 and NGC 4579) is an intermediate barred spiral galaxy with a weak inner ring structure located within the constellation Virgo, approximately 68 million light-years away from Earth. It was discovered by Charles Messier on April 15, 1779 and is one of four barred spiral galaxies that appear in Messier's catalogue. M58 is one of the brightest galaxies in the Virgo Cluster. From 1779 it was arguably (though unknown at that time) the farthest known astronomical object until the release of the New General Catalogue in the 1880s and even more so the publishing of redshift values in the 1920s. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.7, apparent size 5.9′ × 4.7′.

M59.name: Elliptical Galaxy
M59.description: M59 (Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 55,000–65,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.6, spanning roughly 5.4′ × 3.7′. It was discovered by Johann Gottfried Koehler in 1779. Messier 59 or M59, also known as NGC 4621, is an elliptical galaxy in the equatorial constellation of Virgo. It is a member of the Virgo Cluster, with the nearest fellow member 8′ away and around 5 magnitudes fainter. The nearest cluster member of comparable brightness is the lenticular galaxy NGC 4638, which is around 17′ away. It and the angularly nearby elliptical galaxy Messier 60 were both discovered by Johann Gottfried Koehler in April 1779 when observing comet seeming close by. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.6, apparent size 5.4′ × 3.7′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M60.name: Elliptical Galaxy
M60.description: M60 (Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 51,000–59,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.8, spanning roughly 7.4′ × 6.0′. It was discovered by Johann Gottfried Koehler in 1779. Messier 60 or M60, also known as NGC 4649, is an elliptical galaxy approximately 57 million light-years away in the equatorial constellation of Virgo. Together with NGC 4647, it forms a pair known as Arp 116. Messier 60 and nearby elliptical galaxy Messier 59 were discovered by Johann Gottfried Koehler in April 1779, observing a comet in the same part of the sky. Charles Messier added both to his catalogue about three days after this. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.8, apparent size 7.4′ × 6.0′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M61.name: Barred Spiral Galaxy
M61.description: M61 (Barred Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 50,200–54,800 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.7, spanning roughly 6.5′ × 5.8′. It was discovered by Barnaba Oriani in 1779. Messier 61 (also known as M61, NGC 4303, or the Swelling Spiral Galaxy) is an intermediate barred spiral galaxy in the Virgo Cluster of galaxies. It was first discovered by Barnaba Oriani on May 5, 1779, six days before Charles Messier discovered the same galaxy. Messier had observed it on the same night as Oriani but had mistaken it for a comet. Its distance has been estimated to be 45.61 million light years from the Milky Way Galaxy. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.7, apparent size 6.5′ × 5.8′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M62.name: Globular Cluster
M62.description: M62 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Ophiuchus about 22.2 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.5, spanning roughly 15′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1772. Messier 62 or M62, also known as NGC 6266 or the Flickering Globular Cluster, is a globular cluster of stars in the south of the equatorial constellation of Ophiuchus. It was discovered in 1771 by Charles Messier, then added to his catalogue eight years later. M62 is about 21.5 kly from Earth and 5.5 kly from the Galactic Center. It is among the ten most massive and luminous globular clusters in the Milky Way, showing an integrated absolute magnitude of −9.18. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Ophiuchus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.5, apparent size 15′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M63.name: Sunflower Galaxy
M63.description: M63 (Sunflower Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Canes Venatici about 37,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.6, spanning roughly 12.6′ × 7.2′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1779. Messier 63 or M63, also known as NGC 5055 or the seldom-used Sunflower Galaxy, is a spiral galaxy in the northern constellation of Canes Venatici with approximately 400 billion stars. M63 was first discovered by the French astronomer Pierre Méchain, then later verified by his colleague Charles Messier on 14 June 1779. The galaxy became listed as object 63 in the Messier Catalogue. In the mid-19th century, Anglo-Irish astronomer Lord Rosse identified spiral structures within the galaxy, making this one of the first galaxies in which such structure was identified. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Canes Venatici. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.6, apparent size 12.6′ × 7.2′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M64.name: Black Eye Galaxy
M64.description: M64 (Black Eye Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Coma Berenices about 22,000–26,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.5, spanning roughly 10.7′ × 5.1′. It was discovered by Edward Pigott in 1779. The Black Eye Galaxy (also called Sleeping Beauty Galaxy or Evil Eye Galaxy and designated Messier 64, M64, or NGC 4826) is a relatively isolated spiral galaxy 17 million light-years away in the mildly northern constellation of Coma Berenices. It was discovered by Edward Pigott in March 1779, and independently by Johann Elert Bode in April of the same year, as well as by Charles Messier the next year. A dark band of absorbing dust partially in front of its bright nucleus gave rise to its nicknames of the "Black Eye", "Evil Eye", or "Sleeping Beauty" galaxy. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Coma Berenices. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.5, apparent size 10.7′ × 5.1′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M65.name: Spiral Galaxy
M65.description: M65 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Leo about 41,000–42,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.3, spanning roughly 8.7′ × 2.5′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. Messier 65 (also known as NGC 3623) is an intermediate spiral galaxy about 35 million light-years away in the constellation Leo, within its highly equatorial southern half. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. With M66 and NGC 3628, it forms the Leo Triplet, a small close group of galaxies. == Discovery == M65 was discovered by Charles Messier and included in his Messier Objects list. However, William Henry Smyth accidentally attributed the discovery to Pierre Méchain in his popular 19th-century astronomical work A Cycle of Celestial Objects (stating "They [M65 and M66] were pointed out by Méchain to Messier in 1780"). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Leo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.3, apparent size 8.7′ × 2.5′.

M66.name: Spiral Galaxy
M66.description: M66 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Leo about 31,000–41,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.9, spanning roughly 9.1′ × 4.2′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. Messier 66 or M66, also known as NGC 3627, is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the southern, equatorial half of Leo. It was discovered by French astronomer Charles Messier on 1 March 1780, who described it as "very long and very faint". This galaxy is a member of a small group of galaxies that includes M65 and NGC 3628, known as the Leo Triplet or the M66 Group. M65 and M66 are a common object for amateur astronomic observation, being separated by only 20′. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Leo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.9, apparent size 9.1′ × 4.2′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M67.name: Open Cluster
M67.description: M67 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Cancer about 2.61–2.93 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.1, spanning roughly 30′. It was discovered by Johann Gottfried Koehler in 1779. Messier 67 (also known as M67 or NGC 2682) and sometimes called the King Cobra Cluster or the Golden Eye Cluster is an open cluster in the southern, equatorial half of Cancer. It was discovered by Johann Gottfried Koehler in 1779. Estimates of its age range between 3.2 and 5 billion years. Distance estimates are likewise varied, but typically are 800–900 parsecs (2,600–2,900 ly). Estimates of 855, 840, and 815 pc were established via binary star modelling and infrared color-magnitude diagram fitting. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Cancer. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.1, apparent size 30′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M68.name: Globular Cluster
M68.description: M68 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Hydra about 33.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.8, spanning roughly 11′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. Messier 68 (also known as M68 or NGC 4590) is a globular cluster found in the east south-east of Hydra, away from its precisely equatorial part. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. William Herschel described it as "a beautiful cluster of stars, extremely rich, and so compressed that most of the stars are blended together". His son John noted that it was "all clearly resolved into stars of 12th magnitude, very loose and ragged at the borders". Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Hydra. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.8, apparent size 11′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M69.name: Globular Cluster
M69.description: M69 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 29.7 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.6, spanning roughly 10.8′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. Messier 69 or M69, also known NGC 6637, and NGC 6634, is a globular cluster in the southern constellation of Sagittarius. It can be found 2.5° to the northeast of the star Epsilon Sagittarii and is dimly visible in 50 mm aperture binoculars. The cluster was discovered by Charles Messier on August 31, 1780, the same night he discovered M70. At the time, he was searching for an object described by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in 1751–2 and thought he had rediscovered it, but it is unclear if Lacaille actually described M69. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.6, apparent size 10.8′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M70.name: Globular Cluster
M70.description: M70 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 29.4 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.9, spanning roughly 8′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. Messier 70 or M70, also known as NGC 6681, is a globular cluster of stars to be found in the south of Sagittarius. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. The famous comet Hale–Bopp was discovered near this cluster in 1995. It is about 29,400 light years away from Earth and around 6,500 light-years from the Galactic Center. It is roughly the same size and luminosity as its neighbour in space, M69. M70 has a very small core radius of 0.22 ly (0.068 pc) and a half-light radius of 182.0 ly (55.80 pc). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.9, apparent size 8′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M71.name: Globular Cluster
M71.description: M71 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagitta about 13.0 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.2, spanning roughly 7.2′. It was discovered by Philippe Loys de Chseaux in 1745. Messier 71 (also known as M71, NGC 6838, or the Angelfish Cluster) is a globular cluster in the small northern constellation Sagitta. It was discovered by Philippe Loys de Chéseaux in 1745 and included by Charles Messier in his catalog of non-comet-like objects in 1780. It was also noted by Koehler at Dresden around 1775. Messier 71 is also known as NGC 6839, though this identification is very uncertain. This star cluster is about 13,000 light years away from Earth and spans 27 light-years (8 pc). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Sagitta. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.2, apparent size 7.2′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M72.name: Globular Cluster
M72.description: M72 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Aquarius about 53.40–55.74 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.3, spanning roughly 6.6′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 72 (also known as M72 or NGC 6981) is a globular cluster in the south west of the very mildly southern constellation of Aquarius. == Observational history and guide == M72 was discovered by astronomer Pierre Méchain in 1780. His countryman Charles Messier looked for it 36 days later, and included it in his catalog. Both opted for the then-dominant of the competing terms for such objects, considering it a faint nebula rather than a cluster. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Aquarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.3, apparent size 6.6′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M73.name: Asterism
M73.description: M73 (Asterism) is a asterism in the constellation Aquarius about ~2.5 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.0, spanning roughly 2.8′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 73 (M73, also known as NGC 6994) is an asterism of four stars in the constellation Aquarius which was long thought to be a small open cluster. It lies several arcminutes east of globular cluster M72. According to Gaia EDR3, the stars are 1030±9, 1249±10, 2170±22, and 2290±24 light-years from the Sun, with the second being a binary star. == History == M73 was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780 who originally described the object as a cluster of four stars with some nebulosity. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Aquarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.0, apparent size 2.8′. Broadband capture is a safe starting point. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M74.name: Spiral Galaxy
M74.description: M74 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Pisces about 24,000–36,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.4, spanning roughly 10.5′ × 9.5′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1780. Messier 74 (also known as NGC 628 and Phantom Galaxy) is a large spiral galaxy in the equatorial constellation Pisces. It is about 32 million light-years away from Earth. The galaxy contains two clearly defined spiral arms and is therefore used as an archetypal example of a grand design spiral galaxy. The galaxy's low surface brightness makes it the most difficult Messier object for amateur astronomers to observe. Its relatively large angular (that is, apparent) size and the galaxy's face-on orientation make it an ideal object for professional astronomers who want to study spiral arm structure and spiral density waves. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Pisces. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.4, apparent size 10.5′ × 9.5′.

M75.name: Globular Cluster
M75.description: M75 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Sagittarius about 67.5 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.5, spanning roughly 6.8′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1780. Messier 75 or M75, also known as NGC 6864, is a globular cluster of stars in the southern constellation Sagittarius. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1780 and included in Charles Messier's catalog of comet-like objects that same year. M75 is about 67,500 light years away from Earth and is 14,700 light years away from, and on the opposite side of, the Galactic Center. Its apparent size on the sky translates to a true radius of 67 light years. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Sagittarius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.5, apparent size 6.8′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M76.name: Little Dumbbell
M76.description: M76 (Little Dumbbell) is a planetary nebula in the constellation Perseus about 2.5 kly away. It appears around magnitude 10.1, spanning roughly 2.7′ × 1.8′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1780. The Little Dumbbell Nebula, also known as Messier 76, NGC 650/651, the Barbell Nebula, or the Cork Nebula, is a planetary nebula in the northern constellation of Perseus. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1780 and included in Charles Messier's catalog of comet-like objects as number 76. It was first classified as a planetary nebula in 1918 by the astronomer Heber Doust Curtis. However, others might have previously recognized it as a planetary nebula; for example, William Huggins found its spectrum indicated it was a nebula (instead of a galaxy or a star cluster); and Isaac Roberts in 1891 suggested that M76 might be similar to the Ring Nebula (M57), as seen instead from the side view. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Perseus.

M77.name: Barred Spiral Galaxy
M77.description: M77 (Barred Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Cetus about 47,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.9, spanning roughly 7.1′ × 6.0′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1780. Messier 77 (M77), also known as NGC 1068 or the Squid Galaxy, is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus. It is about 47 million light-years (14 Mpc) away from Earth, and was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1780, who originally described it as a nebula. Méchain then communicated his discovery to Charles Messier, who subsequently listed the object in his catalog. Both Messier and William Herschel described this galaxy as a star cluster. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Cetus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.9, apparent size 7.1′ × 6.0′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M78.name: Reflection Nebula
M78.description: M78 (Reflection Nebula) is a reflection nebula in the constellation Orion about 1.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.3, spanning roughly 8′ × 6′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1780. Messier 78 (also known as M78 or NGC 2068) is a reflection nebula in the constellation Orion. It is the brightest diffuse reflection nebula in a group that includes NGC 2064, NGC 2067, and NGC 2071, all part of the Orion B molecular cloud complex. Located approximately 1,350 light-years from Earth, M78 is visible in small telescopes as a hazy patch illuminated by two B-type stars, HD 38563 A and HD 38563 B, of 10th and 11th magnitude. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Orion. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.3, apparent size 8′ × 6′. Broadband works best; narrowband adds little to reflection dust. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M79.name: Globular Cluster
M79.description: M79 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Lepus about 41 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.7, spanning roughly 8.7′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1780. Messier 79 (also known as M79 or NGC 1904) is a globular cluster in the southern constellation Lepus. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1780 and is about 42,000 light-years away from Earth and 60,000 light years from the Galactic Center. Like Messier 54 (the other extragalactic globular on Messier's list), it is believed to not be native to the Milky Way galaxy at all, but instead to the putative Canis Major Dwarf Galaxy, which is currently experiencing a very close encounter with our galaxy. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Lepus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.7, apparent size 8.7′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M80.name: Globular Cluster
M80.description: M80 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Scorpius about 32.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.3, spanning roughly 10′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 80 (also known as M80 or NGC 6093) is a globular cluster located approximately 32,600 light-years (10,000 pc) from Earth in the constellation Scorpius. Discovered by Charles Messier in 1781, it is one of the densest globular clusters in the Milky Way, containing several hundred thousand stars within a spatial diameter of about 95 light-years. The cluster is situated in the Galactic halo, more than twice as distant as the Galactic Center, and lies midway between the stars α Scorpii (Antares) and β Scorpii in a region rich with nebulæ. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Scorpius. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.3, apparent size 10′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution.

M81.name: Bode's Galaxy
