M81.description: M81 (Bode's Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major about 11,400–12,200 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.9, spanning roughly 26.9′ × 14.1′. It was discovered by Johann Elert Bode in 1774. Messier 81 (also known as NGC 3031 or Bode's Galaxy) is a grand design spiral galaxy about 12 million light-years away in the constellation Ursa Major. It has a D25 isophotal diameter of 29.44 kiloparsecs (96,000 light-years). Because of its relative proximity to the Milky Way galaxy, large size, and active galactic nucleus (which harbors a 70 million M☉ supermassive black hole), Messier 81 has been studied extensively by professional astronomers. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Ursa Major. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.9, apparent size 26.9′ × 14.1′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M82.name: Cigar Galaxy
M82.description: M82 (Cigar Galaxy) is a starburst galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major about 10,700–12,300 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.4, spanning roughly 11.2′ × 4.3′. It was discovered by Johann Elert Bode in 1774. Messier 82 (also known as NGC 3034, Cigar Galaxy or M82) is a starburst galaxy approximately 12 million light-years away in the constellation Ursa Major. It is the second-largest member of the M81 Group, with the D25 isophotal diameter of 12.52 kiloparsecs (40,800 light-years). It is about five times more luminous than the Milky Way and its central region is about one hundred times more luminous. The starburst activity is thought to have been triggered by interaction with neighboring galaxy M81. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Ursa Major. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.4, apparent size 11.2′ × 4.3′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M83.name: Southern Pinwheel
M83.description: M83 (Southern Pinwheel) is a galaxy in the constellation Hydra about 14,700 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.6, spanning roughly 12.9′ × 11.5′. It was discovered by Nicolas Louis de Lacaille in 1752. Messier 83 or M83, also known as the Southern Pinwheel Galaxy and NGC 5236, is a barred spiral galaxy approximately 15 million light-years away in the constellation borders of Hydra and Centaurus. Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille discovered M83 on 17 February 1752 at the Cape of Good Hope. Charles Messier added it to his catalogue of nebulous objects (now known as the Messier Catalogue) in March 1781. It is one of the closest and brightest barred spiral galaxies in the sky, and is visible with binoculars. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Hydra. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.6, apparent size 12.9′ × 11.5′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M84.name: Elliptical Galaxy
M84.description: M84 (Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 57,000–63,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.1, spanning roughly 6.5′ × 5.6′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 84 or M84, also known as NGC 4374, is a giant elliptical or lenticular galaxy in the constellation Virgo. Charles Messier discovered the object in 1781 in a systematic search for "nebulous objects" in the night sky. It is the 84th object in the Messier Catalogue and in the heavily populated core of the Virgo Cluster of galaxies, part of the local supercluster. This galaxy has morphological classification E1, denoting it has flattening of about 10%. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.1, apparent size 6.5′ × 5.6′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M85.name: Lenticular Galaxy
M85.description: M85 (Lenticular Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Coma Berenices about 56,000–64,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.1, spanning roughly 7.1′ × 5.5′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 85 (also known as M85 or NGC 4382 or PGC 40515 or ISD 0135852) is a lenticular galaxy, or elliptical galaxy for other authors, in the Coma Berenices constellation. It is 60 million light-years away, and has a diameter of about 36.99 kiloparsecs (120,600 light-years) across. Pierre Méchain discovered M85 in 1781. It is within the outskirts of the Virgo Cluster, and is relatively isolated. Use dithering and good calibration frames, and expect improved contrast with steady seeing. Use dithering and good calibration frames, and expect improved contrast with steady seeing. Use dithering and good calibration frames, and expect improved contrast with steady seeing.

M86.name: Elliptical Galaxy
M86.description: M86 (Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 49,000–55,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.9, spanning roughly 8.9′ × 5.8′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 86 (also known as M86 or NGC 4406) is a bright elliptical or lenticular galaxy in the constellation of Virgo. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. M86 lies in the heart of the Virgo Cluster of galaxies and forms a most conspicuous group with another large galaxy known as Messier 84. It displays the highest blue shift of all Messier objects, as it is, net of its other vectors of travel, approaching the Milky Way at 244 km/s. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.9, apparent size 8.9′ × 5.8′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M87.name: Virgo A
M87.description: M87 (Virgo A) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 51,870–55,130 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.6, spanning roughly 7.2′ × 6.8′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 87 (also known as Virgo A or NGC 4486, generally abbreviated to M87) is a supergiant elliptical galaxy in the constellation Virgo that contains several trillion stars. One of the largest and most massive galaxies in the local universe, it has a large population of globular clusters—about 15,000 compared with the 150–200 orbiting the Milky Way—and a jet of energetic plasma that originates at the core and extends at least 1,500 parsecs (4,900 light-years), traveling at a relativistic speed. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.6, apparent size 7.2′ × 6.8′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M88.name: Spiral Galaxy
M88.description: M88 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Coma Berenices about 39,000–56,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.6, spanning roughly 6.9′ × 3.7′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 88 (also known as M88 or NGC 4501) is a spiral galaxy about 50 to 60 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Coma Berenices. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. == Properties == M88 is one of the fifteen Messier objects that belong to the nearby Virgo Cluster of galaxies. It is galaxy number 1401 in the Virgo Cluster Catalogue (VCC) of 2096 galaxies that are candidate members of the cluster. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Coma Berenices. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.6, apparent size 6.9′ × 3.7′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M89.name: Elliptical Galaxy
M89.description: M89 (Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 47,000–53,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.8, spanning roughly 5.1′ × 4.7′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 89 (M89 for short, also known as NGC 4552) is an elliptical galaxy in the constellation Virgo. It was discovered by Charles Messier on March 18, 1781. M89 is a member of the Virgo Cluster of galaxies. == Features == Current observations allow the possibility that M89 may be nearly perfectly spherical. Distinct flattening as ellipsoids is found in all easily measurable comparators up to a few times of its distance. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.8, apparent size 5.1′ × 4.7′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M90.name: Spiral Galaxy
M90.description: M90 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 55,900–61,500 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.5, spanning roughly 9.5′ × 4.4′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 90 (also known as M90 and NGC 4569) is an intermediate spiral galaxy exhibiting a weak inner ring structure about 60 million light-years away[a] in the constellation Virgo. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. == Membership of the Virgo Cluster == Messier 90 is a member of the Virgo Cluster, being one of its largest and brightest spiral galaxies, with an absolute magnitude of around −22 (brighter than the Andromeda Galaxy). Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.5, apparent size 9.5′ × 4.4′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M91.name: Barred Spiral Galaxy
M91.description: M91 (Barred Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Coma Berenices about 47,000–79,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 10.2, spanning roughly 5.4′ × 4.3′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 91 (also known as NGC 4548 or M91) is a barred spiral galaxy that is found in the south of Coma Berenices. It is in the local supercluster and is part of the Virgo Cluster of galaxies. It is about 63 million light-years away from our galaxy. It was the last of a group of eight "nebulae" – the term 'galaxy' only coming into use for these objects once it was realized in the 20th century that they were extragalactic – discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Coma Berenices. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 10.2, apparent size 5.4′ × 4.3′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M92.name: Globular Cluster
M92.description: M92 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Hercules about 26.7 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.4, spanning roughly 14′. It was discovered by Johann Elert Bode in 1777. Messier 92 (also known as M92, M 92, or NGC 6341) is a globular cluster of stars in the northern constellation of Hercules. == Discovery == It was discovered by Johann Elert Bode on December 27, 1777, then published in the Berliner Astronomisches Jahrbuch during 1779. It was inadvertently rediscovered by Charles Messier on March 18, 1781, and added as the 92nd entry in his catalogue. William Herschel first resolved individual stars in 1783. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Hercules. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.4, apparent size 14′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M93.name: Open Cluster
M93.description: M93 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Puppis about 3.6 kly away. It appears around magnitude 6.0, spanning roughly 10′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. Messier 93 or M93, also known as NGC 2447 or the Critter Cluster, is an open cluster in the modestly southern constellation Puppis, the imagined poop deck of the legendary Argo. == Observational history and appearance == It was discovered by Charles Messier then added to his catalogue of comet-like objects in 1781. Caroline Herschel, the younger sister of William Herschel, independently discovered it in 1783, thinking it had not yet been catalogued by Messier. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Puppis. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 6.0, apparent size 10′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast.

M94.name: Spiral Galaxy
M94.description: M94 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Canes Venatici about 14,700–17,300 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.2, spanning roughly 11.2′ × 9.1′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 94 (also known as NGC 4736, Cat's Eye Galaxy, Crocodile Eye Galaxy, or Croc's Eye Galaxy) is a spiral galaxy in the mid-northern constellation Canes Venatici. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781, and catalogued by Charles Messier two days later. Although some references describe M94 as a barred spiral galaxy, the "bar" structure appears to be more oval-shaped. The galaxy has two ring structures. == Structure == M94 is classified as having a low ionization nuclear emission region (LINER) nucleus. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Canes Venatici. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.2, apparent size 11.2′ × 9.1′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M95.name: Barred Spiral Galaxy
M95.description: M95 (Barred Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Leo about 31,200–34,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.7, spanning roughly 3.1′ × 2.9′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 95, also known as M95 or NGC 3351, is a barred spiral galaxy about 33 million light-years away in the zodiac constellation Leo. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781, and catalogued by compatriot Charles Messier four days later. In 2012 its most recent supernova was discovered. The galaxy has a morphological classification of SB(r)b, with the SBb notation indicating it is a barred spiral with arms that are intermediate on the scale from tightly to loosely wound, and an "(r)" meaning an inner ring surrounds the bar. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Leo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.7, apparent size 3.1′ × 2.9′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M96.name: Spiral Galaxy
M96.description: M96 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Leo about 28,000–34,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.2, spanning roughly 7.6′ × 5.2′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 96 (also known as M96 or NGC 3368) is an intermediate spiral galaxy about 31 million light-years away in the constellation Leo. == Observational history and appearance == M96 was discovered by French astronomer Pierre Méchain on March 20, 1781. After communicating his finding, French astronomer Charles Messier confirmed the finding four days later and added it to his catalogue of nebulous objects. Finding this object is burdensome with large binoculars. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Leo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.2, apparent size 7.6′ × 5.2′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M97.name: Owl Nebula
M97.description: M97 (Owl Nebula) is a planetary nebula in the constellation Ursa Major about 2.03 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.9, spanning roughly 3.4′ × 3.3′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. The Owl Nebula (also known as Messier 97, M97 or NGC 3587) is a planetary nebula approximately 2,030 light years away in the constellation Ursa Major. Estimated to be about 8,000 years old, it is approximately circular in cross-section with a faint internal structure. It was formed from the outflow of material from the stellar wind of the central star as it evolved along the asymptotic giant branch. The nebula is arranged in three concentric shells, with the outermost shell being about 20–30% larger than the inner shell. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Ursa Major. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.9, apparent size 3.4′ × 3.3′. OIII and Ha help pull out the shell and faint halos. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M98.name: Spiral Galaxy
M98.description: M98 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Coma Berenices about 44,400 kly away. It appears around magnitude 10.1, spanning roughly 9.8′ × 2.8′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 98, M98 or NGC 4192, is an intermediate spiral galaxy about 44.4 million light-years away in slightly northerly Coma Berenices, about 6° to the east of the bright star Denebola (Beta Leonis). It was discovered by French astronomer Pierre Méchain on 1781, along with nearby M99 and M100, and was catalogued by compatriot Charles Messier 29 days later in his Catalogue des Nébuleuses & des amas d'Étoiles. It has a blueshift, denoting ignoring of its fast other movement (vectors of proper motion), it is approaching at about 140 km/s. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Coma Berenices. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 10.1, apparent size 9.8′ × 2.8′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M99.name: Pinwheel Galaxy
M99.description: M99 (Pinwheel Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Coma Berenices about 44,700–55,700 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.9, spanning roughly 5.4′ × 4.7′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 99 or M99, also known as NGC 4254 or St. Catherine's Wheel, is a grand design spiral galaxy in the northern constellation Coma Berenices approximately 15,000,000 parsecs (49,000,000 light-years) from the Milky Way. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain on 17 March 1781. The discovery was then reported to Charles Messier, who included the object in the Messier Catalogue of comet-like objects. It was one of the first galaxies in which a spiral pattern was seen. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Coma Berenices. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.9, apparent size 5.4′ × 4.7′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M100.name: Spiral Galaxy
M100.description: M100 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Coma Berenices about 55,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.3, spanning roughly 7.4′ × 6.3′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 100 (also known as NGC 4321 or the Mirror Galaxy) is a grand design intermediate spiral galaxy in the southern part of the mildly northern Coma Berenices. It is one of the brightest and largest galaxies in the Virgo Cluster and is approximately 55 million light-years from our galaxy, about 166,000 light-years in diameter. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781 and 29 days later seen again and entered by Charles Messier in his catalogue "of nebulae and star clusters". Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Coma Berenices. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.3, apparent size 7.4′ × 6.3′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M101.name: Pinwheel Galaxy
M101.description: M101 (Pinwheel Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major about 19,100–22,400 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.9, spanning roughly 28.8′ × 26.9′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. The Pinwheel Galaxy (also known as Messier 101, M101 or NGC 5457) is a face-on, counterclockwise intermediate spiral galaxy located 21 million light-years (6.4 megaparsecs) from Earth in the constellation Ursa Major. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781 and was communicated that year to Charles Messier, who verified its position for inclusion in the Messier Catalogue as one of its final entries. On February 28, 2006, NASA and the European Space Agency released a very detailed image of the Pinwheel Galaxy, which was the largest and most detailed image of a galaxy by Hubble Space Telescope at the time. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Ursa Major. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.9, apparent size 28.8′ × 26.9′.

M102.name: Spindle Galaxy
M102.description: M102 (Spindle Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Draco about 50,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.9, spanning roughly 4.7′ × 1.9′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 102 (also known as M102) is a galaxy listed in the Messier Catalogue that cannot be unambiguously identified. Its original discoverer Pierre Méchain retracted his discovery two years after publication and said that it was a duplicate observation of Messier 101. Later historical evidence favors that M102 is actually the galaxy NGC 5866, although other galaxies have been suggested as possible identities. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) considers it to be the same as NGC 5866. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Draco. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.9, apparent size 4.7′ × 1.9′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M103.name: Open Cluster
M103.description: M103 (Open Cluster) is a open cluster in the constellation Cassiopeia about 10 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.4, spanning roughly 6′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 103 (also known as M103, or NGC 581) is a small open cluster of many faint stars in Cassiopeia. It was discovered on 27 March 1781 by Pierre Méchain, but later added as Charles Messier's last deep-sky object in his catalogue. It is located 9,400 light-years from the Sun and is about 15 light years across. It holds two prominent stars, of which the brightest is magnitude 10.5, and in the center of the cluster, another magnitude 10.8 red giant. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Cassiopeia. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.4, apparent size 6′. Broadband is sufficient; shorter subs keep bright stars tight. Moderate skies are workable, but darker sites improve contrast. Capture tips: ISO 1600+ (or gain ~100-200), 120-300s subs, and 2-6 hours total integration.

M104.name: Sombrero Galaxy
M104.description: M104 (Sombrero Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Virgo about 28,700–30,900 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.0, spanning roughly 9′ × 4′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. The Sombrero Galaxy (also known as Messier Object 104, M104 or NGC 4594) is a peculiar galaxy of unclear classification in the constellation borders of Virgo and Corvus, being about 9.55 megaparsecs (31.1 million light-years) from the Milky Way galaxy. It is a member of the Virgo II Groups, a series of galaxies and galaxy clusters strung out from the southern edge of the Virgo Supercluster. It has an isophotal diameter of approximately 29.09 to 32.32 kiloparsecs (94,900 to 105,000 light-years), making it slightly larger than the Milky Way. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Virgo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.0, apparent size 9′ × 4′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M105.name: Elliptical Galaxy
M105.description: M105 (Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Leo about 30,400–33,600 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.3, spanning roughly 5.4′ × 4.8′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 105 or M105, also known as NGC 3379, is an elliptical galaxy 36.6 million light-years away in the equatorial constellation of Leo. It is the biggest elliptical galaxy in the Messier catalogue that is not in the Virgo cluster. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781, just a few days after he discovered the nearby galaxies Messier 95 and Messier 96. This galaxy is one of a few not object-verified by Messier so omitted in the editions of his Catalogue of his era. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Leo. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.3, apparent size 5.4′ × 4.8′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M106.name: Spiral Galaxy
M106.description: M106 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Canes Venatici about 22,200–25,200 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.4, spanning roughly 18.6′ × 7.2′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 106 (also known as NGC 4258) is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation Canes Venatici. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781. M106 is at a distance of about 22 to 25 million light-years away from Earth. M106 contains an active nucleus classified as a Type 2 Seyfert, and the presence of a central supermassive black hole has been demonstrated from radio-wavelength observations of the rotation of a disk of molecular gas orbiting within the inner light-year around the black hole. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Canes Venatici. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.4, apparent size 18.6′ × 7.2′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M107.name: Globular Cluster
M107.description: M107 (Globular Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Ophiuchus about 20.9 kly away. It appears around magnitude 7.9, spanning roughly 10′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1782. Messier 107 or M107, also known as NGC 6171 or the Crucifix Cluster, is a very loose globular cluster in a very mildly southern part of the sky close to the equator in Ophiuchus, and is the last such object in the Messier Catalogue. == Observational history, namings and guide == It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in April 1782, then independently by William Herschel in 1793. Herschel's son, John, in his 1864 General Catalogue, described it as a "globular cluster of stars, large, very rich, very much compressed, round, well resolved, clearly consisting of stars". Astrophotography notes: Sky position: equatorial sky in Ophiuchus. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 7.9, apparent size 10′. No narrowband needed; focus on star color and core resolution.

M108.name: Spiral Galaxy
M108.description: M108 (Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major about 46,000 kly away. It appears around magnitude 10.0, spanning roughly 8.7′ × 2.2′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1782. Messier 108 (also known as NGC 3556, nicknamed the Surfboard Galaxy) is a barred spiral galaxy about 46 million light-years away from Earth in the northern constellation Ursa Major. It was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781 or 1782. From the Earth, this galaxy is seen almost edge-on. This galaxy is an isolated member of the Ursa Major Cloud of galaxies in the local supercluster. It has a morphological classification of type SBbc in the de Vaucouleurs system, which means it is a barred spiral galaxy with somewhat loosely wound arms. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Ursa Major. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 10.0, apparent size 8.7′ × 2.2′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots.

M109.name: Barred Spiral Galaxy
M109.description: M109 (Barred Spiral Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major about 59,500–107,500 kly away. It appears around magnitude 9.8, spanning roughly 7.6′ × 4.7′. It was discovered by Pierre Mchain in 1781. Messier 109 (also known as NGC 3992 or the Vacuum Cleaner Galaxy) is a barred spiral galaxy exhibiting a weak inner ring structure around the central bar approximately 67.2 ± 23 million light-years away in the northern constellation Ursa Major. M109 can be seen south-east of the star Phecda (γ UMa, Gamma Ursa Majoris). == History == Messier 109 was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781. Two years later Charles Messier catalogued the object, as an appended object to his publication. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Ursa Major. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 9.8, apparent size 7.6′ × 4.7′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.

M110.name: Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy
M110.description: M110 (Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy) is a galaxy in the constellation Andromeda about 2,600–2,780 kly away. It appears around magnitude 8.5, spanning roughly 21.9′ × 11.0′. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1773. Messier 110, or M110, also known as NGC 205, is a dwarf elliptical galaxy that is a satellite of the Andromeda Galaxy in the Local Group. == Early observational history == Charles Messier never included the galaxy in his list, but it was depicted by him, together with M32, on his drawing of "Nébuleuse D'Andromède", later known as the Andromeda Galaxy. A label of the drawing indicates that Messier first saw the object in 1773. Astrophotography notes: Sky position: northern sky in Andromeda. Target characteristics: brightness around mag 8.5, apparent size 21.9′ × 11.0′. Broadband LRGB is typical; Ha can highlight star-forming knots. Dark skies (Bortle 4 or better) or narrowband help tease out faint detail.
